posts.name: Gavin Bigham
posts.cooked:
We are using the generic photonvision algae object detection model on an Orange Pi 5, but we are encountering issues with the model detecting reflections on the polycarbonate fences. These reflections have the same or greater confidence levels as normal algae, making it difficult to distinguish between them.

How can we avoid these reflections, or is there a way to filter them out? Has anyone else encountered this problem or used an AI model that could help?

The changes maintain the original meaning while improving readability and grammar.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
Certainly! Here's the cleaned-up text:

"Can you do something as simple as filtering it out when the algae is out of bounds of the field?"

posts.name: Gavin Bigham
posts.cooked: We don't localize the algae detentions; we only receive the offset from the center of the camera to the center of the algae at present.

posts.name: Duncan Macdonald
posts.cooked: A CPL filter can create a similar effect to polarized sunglasses, though polarized sunglasses may introduce some unwanted tint. Iâ€™ve never tested a CPL filter on a robot, so Iâ€™m unsure if it completely eliminates all reflections or just some.
You can also get some CPL film.

posts.name: Roger
posts.cooked:
We had this problem way back in 2007 Rack 'n' Roll with the green light reflecting off the side walls. Our autonomous robot would drive straight, then spin left toward the wall to chase the reflection. We eventually put a piece of cardboard as a blinder on the camera to fix the issue. YMMV.  

The story goes that our mentor was behind Dean and Woodie pondering the cardboard as they watched the match, got an explanation, and then looked at each other and said, "We didn't think of that."  

Duncan Macdonaldâ€™s picture reminded me of 2008 Overdrive ghost robots, also known as "Pepperâ€™s Ghosts" from Disneyâ€™s Haunted Mansion.
